text.content: A guide to setup your NuxtJS project the right way. We'll make certain configurations to improve performance and also make changes to make our life more pleasant

text.content: A NuxtJS Starter Project that you can actually use

title.plain_text: A NuxtJS Starter Project that you can actually use

text.content: In this article, let's set up a NuxtJS project with PWA(Progressive Web Applications) abilities. I'll explain the folder structure, various settings (which you will most likely use) and propose some libraries that you can use to make your life easier.

rich_text.plain_text: In this article, let's set up a NuxtJS project with PWA(Progressive Web Applications) abilities. I'll explain the folder structure, various settings (which you will most likely use) and propose some libraries that you can use to make your life easier.

text.content: is a JavaScript framework built on top of VueJS. Vue is a framework similar to Angular, built by

rich_text.plain_text: is a JavaScript framework built on top of VueJS. Vue is a framework similar to Angular, built by

text.content: , an ex-googler. Nuxt abstracts most of the complex configuration involved in managing things like asynchronous data, middleware, and routing, which helps you focus more on your Business features.

rich_text.plain_text: , an ex-googler. Nuxt abstracts most of the complex configuration involved in managing things like asynchronous data, middleware, and routing, which helps you focus more on your Business features.

text.content: Nuxt solves various shortcomings of VueJS. The first and foremost is -

rich_text.plain_text: Nuxt solves various shortcomings of VueJS. The first and foremost is -

text.content: (SSR). By default, in a typical Vue or similar framework, you receive a barebone HTML with the necessary scripts defined. The client then downloads those JavaScript files which are then responsible for rendering your webpage.

rich_text.plain_text: (SSR). By default, in a typical Vue or similar framework, you receive a barebone HTML with the necessary scripts defined. The client then downloads those JavaScript files which are then responsible for rendering your webpage.

text.content: Search Engine Crawlers don't like this..?

rich_text.plain_text: Search Engine Crawlers don't like this..?

text.content: They want the whole webpage while parsing it. Since your barebone? Html does not have much for the crawler to parse, you get a pretty low SEO score. Hence, it makes sense for a dynamic web application to give the complete HTML in the first place.

rich_text.plain_text: They want the whole webpage while parsing it. Since your barebone? Html does not have much for the crawler to parse, you get a pretty low SEO score. Hence, it makes sense for a dynamic web application to give the complete HTML in the first place.

text.content: Other than SSR, Nuxt brings about host other features such as File System automatic route generation, static site generation, inbuilt router, vuex store, etc.

rich_text.plain_text: Other than SSR, Nuxt brings about host other features such as File System automatic route generation, static site generation, inbuilt router, vuex store, etc.

text.content: directory is where you put all your Vue.js components which are then imported into your pages.Nuxt supports Autoimporting your components but this slows down the Hot Reload. IMO it's not worth it in a small project.

text.content: It's not necessary to create this file, however, it will help your Text Editor during linting and error checking. I'll suggest you create this file. An example file:

rich_text.plain_text: It's not necessary to create this file, however, it will help your Text Editor during linting and error checking. I'll suggest you create this file. An example file:

text.content:
{
  "compilerOptions": {
    "target": "ESNext",
    "module": "ESNext",
    "moduleResolution": "Node",
    "lib": [
      "ESNext",
      "ESNext.AsyncIterable",
      "DOM"
    ],
    "esModuleInterop": true,
    "allowJs": true,
    "sourceMap": true,
    "strict": true,
    "noImplicitAny": false,
    "noEmit": true,
    "experimentalDecorators": true,
    "baseUrl": ".",
    "paths": {
      "~/*": ["./*"],
      "@/*": ["./*"],
      "Images/*":["./assets/images/*"],
      "Styles/*":["./assets/styles/*"]
    },
    "types": [
      "@nuxt/types",
      "@nuxtjs/axios",
      "@types/node"
    ]
  },
  "exclude": [
    "node_modules",
    ".nuxt",
    "dist"
  ]
}

rich_text.plain_text:
{

      "@nuxtjs/axios",
      "@types/node"
    ]
  },
  "exclude": [
    "node_modules",
    ".nuxt",
    "dist"
  ]
}

text.content: For your reference, here are the external configs that I'm using -

rich_text.plain_text: For your reference, here are the external configs that I'm using -

text.content:
export default {
  name: 'limosyn.com',
  lang: 'en',
  short_name: 'limosyn.com',
  scope: "/",
  start_url: '/?source=pwa',
  display: 'standalone',
  background_color: '#edf2f7',
  theme_color: '#9f7aea' // Allows the purple color on Address bar - mobile
}
